The Government must realise that an Amendment on these lines is required, and they should proceed accordingly.

We come now to the most important question of the enforcement of the Clause which we have been considering all night and the procedure for settling disputes.
But, before we consider what sanctions would be appropriate, it is right to pause for a moment and consider what it is we are supposed to enforce.
The Clause to be enforced is one which has received a more substantial, prolonged and effective mauling than almost any other provision can have had in any democratic assembly in recent times. When the Treasury Ministers the there will be engraved on their hearts, if they have hearts, which we sometimes doubted during the night, the words "Clause 43".

Clause 42. [Laughter.] That only shows how one is affected by the long hours of debate which we have just gone through. Clause 42 has been mauled from all sides, without a word being said in its favour.
Bishop Morton had his fork with which he collected taxes from the affluent ostentatious and from the affluent miserly. The Chancellor has gone further and produced a new petard on which he seeks to hoist everyone from charities to dollar earners, right through the categories we were considering throughout the night. It is small consolation that, eventually, he will be hoist by it himself.
We are here considering the enforcement of this bad Clause, Clause 42. How is the Chancellor seeking to enforce payment of the sums which accrue under this Clause? He seeks to do this by the provision of Schedule 10, and to cause the payments to be made to be treated as if they were contributions payable under the National Insurance scheme, thus bringing into play the whole of the mechanism contained in the National Insurance Act, 1965, for the enforcement of the payment of contributions. It is wrong that the same system should be adopted for the collection of contributions as for taxation. The two things are very different, and the system of collection should be different.
The difficulties manifest themselves when one looks at the Act. Section 8 of the Act, which we seek to exclude, says in the first subsection: Subject to the provisions of this Act and of any regulations, no person shall be entitled to pay any contribution under this Act other than a contribution which he is liable to pay.
That seems to be common sense, but it raises a point with which I would like the Financial Secretary to deal. Supposing a charity comes forward and says to an employer that if he employs a disabled person it will pay the employment tax it would be prevented from doing so by the provisions of Section 8 (1) of the Act. Subsection 2 of Section 8 provides that for a failure to pay this tax a person is liable for summary conviction. In other words, a person who did not pay this tax is a criminal. We believe that this is wrong. A person may be disputing the tax. This is surely without precedent and it is the most reprehensible part of the provisions which we are considering.
Section 64 of the 1965 Act raised a host of matters to be determined by the Minister. Is it right that the matters set out in the Section should be determined by the Minister, and that there should only be an appeal on a point of law, as I read it, to the High Court, with no right to appeal from there?
I am no tax lawyer, but I understand that the practice is that one has the right of appeal to the High Court and from there to the Court of Appeal and, when a point of public importance is involved, a right of appeal to the House of Lords. Why should the ordinary citizen, in a consideration of this reprehensible tax which has been condemned by both sides of the Committee, be deprived of the right of appeal which he has relative to his ordinary Income Tax affairs? A proper and effective explanation is needed from the Government as to why the ordinary citizen should be precluded from having the right to go to the Court of Appeal and the House of Lords.
The Amendment deals with the matter in a sensible and straightforward way. I admit that I am not entirely convinced about the need to exclude Section 93 of the National Insurance Act, but the Amendment covers the point admirably. It puts back fairly and squarely matters of dispute to the courts where they rightly belong. If the Amendment is accepted, as I am sure it will be, in the mellow light of dawn when tranquillity descends over the Committee and the Financial Secretary is in the mood to accept an Amendment so sensible and cogent as this one, the courts will deal with the matter and there will automatically be a
right of appeal to the Court of Appeal and then, if necessary, to the House of Lords.
We clearly lay down that the payments which fall due under the Clause shall be recoverable as civil debts, which is what they are. There should be no question of a person being branded as a criminal if he defaults on payment and is in dispute with the Ministry as to whether payment is due.
Even Hampden, when he refused to pay ship money, was not branded as a criminal. It is wrong that someone who is in dispute about the payment of tax under this Clause, which has not had a word said in its favour all night, should be liable to conviction and be branded as a criminal, albeit he is subject only to a fine of £10 in the first instance.

I remind the hon. Member for Colchester (Mr. Buck) that a number of very persuasive and cogent speeches have been made in support of the Clause—all coming from the Treasury Bench.
I seek to persuade the Committee, first, why the proposals which the hon. and learned Member for Kensington, South (Mr. Roots) made would result in an unworkable system; and, secondly, why the system proposed in the Clause is logical, fair and sensible, according very closely with other provisions in purely taxation matters.
First, as to workability, the liability for the tax is imposed on the employer who is liable to pay a National Insurance contribution. That is how it is defined from the outset in the Clause. There cannot be any other person liable to pay the tax than the person liable to pay the National Insurance contribution. Secondly, the tax is to be paid with and under the same stamp and as if it were part of the National Insurance contribution. The elements get married by Schedule 10, just as in the same way that the liability to pay several different elements is already married in the existing National Insurance stamp, which includes contributions not just to one fund but to about four different funds.
Clearly, therefore, unless one is to get back to the sort of confusion between the different systems of tribunal which we had before the Judicature Act in the last century, it is necessary that the same
courts should determine the same issues, whether in relation to the existing liability under the existing stamp or the additional liability which is added to that by the Clause in respect of this tax. It would, therefore, be unworkable if one had one court, one set of proceedings, to determine, for example, who was the employer, to determine the liability to pay in respect of the National Insurance element of the stamp, and another different set of proceedings and a different set of courts to determine exactly the same issue in relation to the employer's liability to pay this tax with the stamp. One could get conflicting decisions from different tribunals. That is something, as I say, which was familiar to our legal system when we had conflict of jurisdiction between the Chancery and Common Law courts prior to the Judicature Act. I do not think any lawyer or any hon. Member would want us to go back and try that sort of confusion again.
The hon. and learned Gentleman will no doubt bear in mind that under the old system which he is describing the rules of equity always prevailed?

That was the theory, of course, but the kind of proceedings which were sometimes taken to make it prevail included attachment and consigning parties to prison because they dared to try to exercise any different and legal jurisdiction. I do not know whether the hon. Member wants to return to those days, but I suspect not.
Secondly, may I just outline, and answer detailed points on it which were raised, what the procedure is and compare it with procedures under taxation Statutes. At the moment the employer's liability to pay a contribution—to deal with that aspect first, and enforcement afterwards—is first referred to a legal officer of the Ministry of Pensions and National Insurance, who would express his opinion; he cannot determine the issue, but he will give guidance. The employer, if the employer does not agree with his ruling, can then make application for a formal decision by the Minister. The Minister is then acting in a quasi judicial capacity in making that decision. If the Minister thinks right, he
may, and frequently does, then order an inquiry to be held into the facts. It is conducted by a lawyer. The employer can be represented legally at that inquiry, and evidence is taken on oath. A report is then made to the Minister by the inspector who has held the inquiry on the findings of fact. The Minister then reaches his decision upon that report and makes the decision. There is then a right of appeal, by way of case stated, on points of law to the High Court, and this is an appeal to a High Court judge sitting alone, and he is the final tribunal in that determination.
With regard to the non-compliance proceedings for the recovery of the contribution, there are two types of proceedings, both criminal and civil. The criminal proceedings are regarded as appropriate where there is evidence that there has been deliberate evasion. The civil proceedings are normally taken in the ordinary case where there appears to have been some misunderstanding, or where, for example, there is an instalment arrangement which has been partly carried out but has subsequently broken down.
This is, I take it, a purely Ministerial decision? It is for the Minister to decide whether to take criminal or civil proceedings? Is that accurate?

That is quite correct. Is is for the Minister to decide which proceedings to launch. I am stating what the practice is and the principle upon which that decision is made. Of course, this system has been operating now for a very considerable time—so far as I know, without criticism either from the courts or generally. In fact, the majority of cases which are taken against employers are taken by way of civil proceedings rather than by way of criminal proceedings.
7.45 a.m.
The civil proceedings are taken normally in the county court unless the amount involved exceeds the county court jurisdiction, in which case they have to be taken in the high court. The criminal procedings are in form criminal proceedings but they are in a very real sense proceedings for recovery of the amount outstanding. The form of the proceedings is a complaint as to the failure to pay a particular contribution within the time prescribed, which is an offence under
the National Insurance Acts. The penalty is £10. That is the extent of the criminal jurisdiction to which the recovery proceedings are anchored, because the court may order payment of the amount of the National Insurance contribution in those proceedings if an appropriate notice has been served beforehand by the Minister upon the employer. That is then recoverable as if it were a penalty, so that the payment can be enforced as if the sum were a fine.
In the case of Leach v. Litchfield in 1960 the Lord Chief Justice emphasised that this procedure was civil in nature despite the provision that the amount of the order was recoverable as a penalty. This procedure, which in a sense combines criminal and civil aspects, was commended by Lord Goddard for its simplicity and effectiveness, and he commended it as a type of proceedings. I do not say that it is without precedent, but it has novel features in our system. So it is not merely that it has found general acceptance in practice from the public and employers, but it has been spoken of with approval by none other than the Lord Chief Justice.
Let us compare that with some of the procedures in relation to employers' liability on the Income Tax side and in relation to Purchase Tax. Dealing with P.A.Y.E. first, on the question of recovery of amounts outstanding, where the Inland Revenue decides to take proceedings against an employer for holding back an employee's tax which he has deducted, it is rather different. This is how the employer's liability arises on P.A.Y.E. These proceedings, which are civil proceedings, are taken in a Magistrates' Court where the sum is below £100, in the county court if it is within county court jurisdiction, or in the high court if ft is higher than that.
Any dispute about liability to pay the tax is not a dispute between the employer and the Revenue. It is a dispute between the employee and the Revenue. So there is no real analogy to this. But if the employer holds back from the Inland Revenue the return of employees and wages paid, the Inland Revenue then can take civil penalty proceedings in the high court, which imposes a statutory fine of £10 a day until the return is made, which, again, is something comparable
to the penalty proceedings in the National Insurance Acts.
In relation to Purchase Tax, the question of liability again may arise. There may be a dispute with the employer in respect of the taxable class in which goods fall. The procedure is very similar. The wholesaler or manufacturer seeks a ruling first from the local office. If he disagrees with that, he can go to higher authority within the department, and if he is not satisfied with the ruling that he gets from the Commissioners, he can appeal to the high court on a point of law. There are various ways in which that can be done. In practice, the most normal way is by a motion for a declaration by the court, which can be in either the Chancery or the Queen's Bench Division. I understand that in practice applicants usually apply to the Chancery Division. There are also various informal procedures which can be adopted.

Is it not correct to say that the procedure which the hon. and learned Gentleman has outlined goes further—usually from the Chancery Division on appeal to the Court of Appeal, and then to the House of Lords?

That is correct. Experience shows, however, that the ability to appeal to the House of Lords or be carried to the House of Lords by the Revenue or the Commissioners by way of appeal is not quite so popular with the general public as it is among lawyers. There has certainly been no great agitation in the National Insurance field—and it is precisely the same issues which have to be decided—that the procedure should be altered so as to give a right of appeal to the House of Lords.
Where a trader or wholesaler does not pay the amount due, the legal proceedings take the form of an action for recovery of a civil debt. Again, there may be criminal proceedings, and they are taken where payment is not made by the due date. It is, in effect, the same formula as for the institution of criminal proceedings under the National Insurance Acts. Again, that form is adopted where there has been wilful refusal either to pay or, at an earlier stage, to cooperate, by refusing to put in a return, which is the basis for assessment. That
is sometimes done as a means for putting off payment of tax.
I hope that the Committee will be satisfied that the National Insurance procedure, without the right of appeal to the House of Lords, follows very closely the accepted procedures in these other fields.
I was asked a point about Section 15 of the National Insurance Act, which gives power for regulations to be made for contributions to be collected with Income Tax. The Section is concerned primarily with the graduated contributions. The Selective Employment Tax is to be collected with the flat rate contributions, which are not paid with Income Tax. In theory, there could be the power to make regulations for the flat rate contributions to be collected with Income Tax. That has not been done, and no such arrangements could be made without very substantial alteration to and reorganisation of the National Insurance system. That is most unlikely to happen. If it did, we could look at any problems which might arise. I think that it is a contingency with which we need not trouble ourselves.
Section 16 deals with regulations to determine the persons to be treated as employers. For the reasons that I have given, we must accept the same proceedings and procedure as we have for the rest of the liabilities which already exist for the insurance stamp.
The hon. Member for Colchester raised the question of Section 8 of the National Insurance Act and invited us to consider the case where a charity said to an employer, "If you employ this disabled man, we will pay the tax element in the stamp." Of course, there is only one stamp, and one stamp has to be bought. Unless the charity also assumed liability for all the rest of the contributions that have to be paid in the National Insurance stamp, presumably it would refund the employer the amount of the Selective Employment Tax within the stamp. If it chose to pay the lot or wanted to pay for the employer, there is no legal reason why it should not,

by a simple agency. It could act as agent for the employer in order to pay it. The legal obligation must remain with the employer, and that would be so whether it was dealt with under Taxation law or under National Insurance law.
Perhaps the hon. and learned Gentleman could explain to me the purpose of Section 8 (1) of the National Insurance Act, 1965.

I think that any further questions on this should be referred to my right hon. Friend the Minister of Pensions and National Insurance. I am only pointing out that these provisions do not offer any obstruction to having a workable system for the purpose of this tax.

I have listened with care to the right hon. Gentleman's explanation. I agree that the same court should deal with the same issues, but my quarrel is that under this Bill, and what I hope I can with propriety refer to as the next Bill, this will not happen.
The Financial Secretary exercised the considerable persuasion of his advocacy to demonstrate that the law had got into such a muddle by having these special provisions for Purchase Tax and every other kind of liability that I cannot help thinking that the lay Members of the Committee must have been horrified at the complexity of it. Lawyers may be thought to welcome this, but it is my experience that they do not.
The major matter still remains that it is high time—and this may be a useful opportunity to do it—that we got back to one system of the established courts dealing with matters such as those arising under this Clause. Similarly, it should be clearly stated that in instances such as this recovery should be as a civil debt, which is what it is. I shall therefore advise my hon. Friends to take the matter to a Division.
Question put, That those words be there inserted:—
The Committee divided: Ayes 80, Noes 124.

tr.td: Gordon Walker, Rt. Hn. P. C.

speech.p: I beg to move Amendment No. 355, in page 49, line 44, to leave out subsection (8) and to insert: (8) The provisions of the selective employment tax shall not apply to Northern Ireland.

I think it would be for the convenience of the Committee to discuss
with this Amendment Amendment No. 353, in page 48, line 35, leave out from "Act" to end of line 38, Amendment No. 354, in page 4, line 7, leave out paragraph (b), Amendment No. 356, in page 50, line 14, leave out paragraph (b), and Amendment No. 357, in page 50, line 23, leave out from 1965 to end of Clause.

Yes, Mr. Irving. This is an unusual Amendment to a Finance Bill. As far as I know, since 1920 there has been only one precedent for it. It is a pity that a subject of this importance should have to be discussed at the end of 16 hours' solid debate, when the Treasury Ministers are obviously wilting and tired. I sympathise with the Chancellor. I have watched him throughout the night, and I admire his stamina, but it is a pity that he should inflict upon himself the task of considering anything of such great importance after such a long night.
But we must deploy the case, whatever the time, and it is a serious one. I want to put a serious argument to the Chancellor. I said that the Amendment was an unusual one. It is unusual in that ever since 1920, when the Government and Parliament of Northern Ireland was set up, we in Northern Ireland have accepted the view that, being an integral part of the United Kingdom, it was right that we should accept not only the benefits that accrued from that but also the obligation of the same taxation throughout the whole of the United Kingdom.
This principle has applied ever since to the provision of revenue. We have always resisted suggestions made, sometimes at home in Ulster, that Northern Ireland should be exempted from this or that tax, or that there should be a different rate of Income Tax in Northern Ireland from that which operates here. Ever since I have been in the House I have resisted any suggestion of a differential in taxation between one part of the Kingdom and another.
But when my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Wirral (Mr. Selwyn Lloyd) introduced the payroll tax in his Budget we came to the conclusion, after considerable thought, that this was so peculiar in its effect upon Northern Ireland that it was inviting the people and the economy of Northern Ireland to pay not a fair share, with the rest of the United Kingdom, but a totally disproportionate share of the burden of taking the heat out of the economy. We came to the conclusion then that a tax upon the employment of labour was grotesque in Northern Ireland, where our problem is the problem of finding work for the people.
Unemployment at the time was running at the rate of 7 or 8 per cent We thought that to impose a tax on the employment of labour in an area where unemployment was running at 6 to 7 per cent. was the most appalling nonsense.
We conducted a long and sustained campaign, mostly behind the scenes, with my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Wirral to convince him that it was inappropriate. After considerable argument we managed to persuade him that the tax was inappropriate and would damage the Northern Ireland economy. My right hon. and learned Friend finally agreed, and the precedent now exists that Northern Ireland should be exempted from a payroll tax. It was established then that, had that Payroll Tax come into operation, Northern Ireland would not have been included in it.
Now we are faced with the Selective Employment Tax. If the Payroll Tax of my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Wirral was inappropriate and damaging to the economy of Northern Ireland, how much more damaging is this extraordinary tax. The object of the tax is not to raise revenue: its declared object is to redeploy labour from service industries into manufacturing industries. In Northern Ireland, this concept does not make sense, because, although the Northern Ireland Government, with the assistance of the Treasury, has made magnificent strides in finding new employment, diversifying our industry and making us less dependent on the old traditional industries which have been steadily running down, the fact remains that unemployment is still at about 6 per cent.
To suggest that, in a situation of that kind, one can do anything to induce anyone who employs labour, in whatever capacity, to release that labour is an extraordinary proposal. I find it hard to believe that the Chancellor—who has taken a great and benevolent interest in our affairs, which we have welcomed—really means this. For example, how could it make sense in Northern Ireland to impose the tax upon the employment of labour in the tourist industry, in hotels and seaside cafes? If the object of the exercise is to induce firms to release some labour, where will that labour go? There
is simply not enough manufacturing industry for it to go to. Nothing would be gained for the national economy, let alone the economy of Northern Ireland.
My hon. Friends will no doubt advance detailed arguments about the detailed effect of the tax on our economy. I should like to meet in advance two arguments which I suspect the Financial Secretary will put forward. He may, first, say, "If we accept the Amendment, manufacturing industries in Northern Ireland will not get a rebate and would not have that advantage, and would therefore be at a disadvantage with their competitors across the Irish Sea."
8.15 a.m.
Of course, technically that would be the effect of carrying this Amendment. But if the Financial Secretary is going to argue that way, surely a better way can be found to provide some form of premium for Ulster manufacturing industries than to induce the Ulster service industries, the construction industry and so on, to provide the money. I should have thought that a better way could be found, and therefore I hope the Financial Secretary will not advance that argument by opposing this Amendment.
The Financial Secretary may also say that this Amendment is not received with great enthusiasm by the Government of Northern Ireland. That is quite possible. It is true that in this arrangement the Treasury has made a concession to us. It has conceded that while the tax is collected in this Finance Bill, the Northern Ireland Government, with the consent of the Northern Ireland Parliament, can produce their own Selective Employment Payments Bill. This will be introduced in the Parliament of Northern Ireland, and I understand that it is the intention of the Ulster Minister of Finance to see to it that there is a repayment right across the board of 12s. 6d.—half the tax.
A temporary payment.

A temporary payment, yes. I was coming to that point. As my hon. Friend the Member for Belfast, North (Mr. Stratton Mills) says, it is a temporary arrangement, and for the first year the burden falling upon the service industries may be only 12s. 6d. per man employed. On the other hand, one does
not know about the second or third or following years if this tax were to continue. We are grateful for the concession. The Northern Ireland Government, of course, are in a pleasant position. I have been in this House for 16 years and I do not remember the Northern Ireland Government—I am talking about Government, not Parliament—being very enthusiastic about a proposition to reduce taxation. If one thinks of it, one will appreciate that it would be unnatural for them to be very enthusiastic. The Northern Ireland Government are able to get the advantages of revenue to spend without the odium of having to impose the tax. As I say, that is perfectly understandable and nobody would criticise it. Nonetheless, that is the situation.
I hope the Financial Secretary will not say that this Amendment does not have the support of the Government of Northern Ireland because that is an argument which does not hold water. I can assure him that it has the support of the Northern Ireland taxpayer. It certainly has the support of the vast majority of the constituents of all of us who sit in this House. I am quite sure that it would have the support of the vast majority of the Members of Parliament of Northern Ireland, if it came to it. However, I hope the Financial Secretary will not use that argument against us.
The fact remains that this is a most extraordinary tax. We have listened for a long time to the arguments about its effect on the tourist, construction and other industries. All those arguments are doubly valid for Northern Ireland. The disabilities for hotels that have been mentioned apply equally to Northern Ireland. But there is the additional disability there in that the men made unemployed will not be able to find other work. Where 6 per cent. of the insured population is out of work, to put a tax upon labour is a grotesque nonsense.
I hope the Government will consider the Amendment very carefully. If they did accept it, we would expect that something would be done to see that our manufacturing industries were not put at a disadvantage vis-á -vis their competitors over here. It is all very well for the hon. Member for Liverpool, West Derby (Mr. Ogden) to laugh. We are dealing with the employment of people. He is laughing at a proposition
that our manufacturing industries in Northern Ireland should not be placed at a disadvantage against their competitors in Great Britain. I am suggesting a better way of ensuring that than by putting a tax on service industries which can only lead to further unemployment.

The hon. Gentleman has not eyes in the back of his head. He could not have been looking in this direction when he made that remark about my laughing. Some of his hon. Friends may have been laughing, but I certainly was not. I was, however, expressing amusement that the hon. Gentleman should ask to be relieved of all responsibility but given all the advantages.

If the hon. Gentleman tells me that he was not laughing, I accept it, but he certainly looked as if he was. I was careful at the beginning of my speech to say that the Northern Ireland people are perfectly prepared to accept their full liabilities as part of the United Kingdom as well as the advantages.
I recall that we also departed from the payroll tax introduced by my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Wirral when he was Chancellor of the Exchequer. We did so because we considered that, with 6 per cent. unemployment, we were being asked to bear an unfair burden. Now we are again being asked to bear an unfair burden. We are willing to bear anything fair but this tax is unfair.
Would the hon. Gentleman apply this argument to Scotland?

Yes, I would, if a way could be found to do it for parts of Scotland at any rate—I am not sure about the whole of the country. I have always thought that a payroll tax should be selective geographically, so as to induce and attract industries to go to development areas. I supported an Amendment related to development areas earlier in the Committee stage. The tax would be much better if it were selective geographically.
I do not want at this hour of the morning to labour the point. I hope that my hon. Friends will make the case in due course in some detail. I ask the Financial
Secretary carefully to consider this matter.

I have great pleasure in supporting the Amendment, which has been so ably moved by my hon. Friend the Member for Down, South (Captain Orr). I am particularly glad that he led for the Amendment today because it was a matter of great regret when I moved a similar Amendment in 1961 that my hon. and gallant Friend did not sign it and support it [HON. MEMBERS: "Oh. Oh."]. We were then fighting over a very small difference. Today I have some hope that the party opposite will support the Amendment.
My hon. Friend said, quite rightly, that he pressed for a special concession for Northern Ireland, and in the debate in 1961, the then Chancellor, the right hon. and learned Member for Wirral (Mr. Selwyn Lloyd), agreed that the money should be paid back to Northern Ireland. This seemed to content quite a lot of my hon. Friends and the then Minister of Finance, who is now the Prime Minister for Northern Ireland. But I and my hon. Friend, Mrs. Patricia McLaughlin, and my hon. Friend the Member for Mid-Ulster (Mr. Forrest), were not satisfied with just that. We wanted to exclude Northern Ireland completely, as indeed we still do today. Therefore we pressed the matter firmly.
The party opposite, who gave me their full support at that time, will probably give me their full support today. When I read the Front Bench speeches that right hon. and hon. Gentlemen opposite on the Treasury Bench made then, I am sure that they were not insincere. I cannot believe that right hon. and hon. Gentlemen opposite would be so hypocritical that they would turn their backs on the many strong and convincing arguments for excluding Northern Ireland from the then comparatively modest payroll tax proposal of only four shillings.
Now that these same men are in office, I ask myself how the Treasury Front Bench could with dignity and honour completely turn about-face and deny the validity of all the arguments that they so recently advanced with such clear and convincing sincerity and conviction in 1961. I tell myself that the right hon. and hon. Gentlemen opposite are men of
honour. They were returned by the electorate and entrusted with very high office of State. They once invited me to show my good faith by voting with them against my own party, and I did vote against my own party. Now, it is my turn to invite right hon. Gentlemen opposite to prove to the nation that they are not two-faced, that they are not the land of rogues who say one thing one day when in opposition and fighting for office and then, when they win a position of trust, turn round and do the opposite.
8.30 a.m.
Before turning to the speeches of the Prime Minister, the First Secretary of State, the President of the Board of Trade and other leading Ministers today, I quote first from the Chancellor's Budget: speech. It has been reported and, I expect, carefully checked by the right hon. Gentleman. Speaking of the economic situation and the balance of payments, he said: The improvement we made in 1965 must be sustained until we generate a surplus. It is my judgment that we shall not do this unless we take firm action at home to release more resources for exports and for the substitution of imports It is against this background that I have considered what additional taxation I should propose At this point I must come back once more to the need to moderate increases in incomes To some extent the answer to the question—'How much extra taxation?'—lies in the hands of those now preparing and negotiating new wage claims. I do not think enough people yet realise the extent to which they hold the key in their own hands If increases in incomes are related to productivity and do not outstrip it, my task is made more easy, and taxation needs to be less fierce."—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 3rd May, 1966; Vol. 728, c. 1451–2.] I am sure the Chancellor will agree that that is the key passage. It was on that that he based his Selective Employment Tax. It is clear from that passage that the Selective Employment Tax is intended as a regulator. It is intended to take the heat out of the economy. He says himself that the public have the answer in their own hands.
This is a tax designed to deflate the overheated British economy, to reduce the pressure of internal demand so that resources and labour will be diverted to boost exports, while, at the same time, our thirst for imports, at least our imports of consumer goods, will be deliberately
restricted. Is not that the reasoning behind this payroll tax?
But the need for such a regulator can hardly be argued in a part of the country where there is no excessive consumer demand, where there is no shortage of labour to drive up wages and salaries in an inflationary spiral. For unemployment stands at a persistent 6 to 7 per cent. in Northern Ireland, and Government policies in regard to aircraft production are about to throw 4,000 more skilled men on to the labour market over the next 18 months. According to an Answer which the Minister of Aviation gave me recently, 4,000 more men are to be released by the end of next year from Short Brothers and Harland.
The Chancellor made very clear that one of the purposes of his regulator was to divert people from consumer and service industries to manufacturing industries. His reason is that there is a shortage of labour in manufacturing industry. But this shortage does not obtain in Northern Ireland. There is no shortage of labour there. There is a surplus in manufacturing, a surplus which will be substantially increased by the run-down of Short Brothers and Harland which the Government themselves have made part of their National Plan.
Clearly, against that background, there can be no need in Northern Ireland for such extra taxation to damp down an over-heated economy.
It may be asked whether Northern Ireland is an area sufficiently clearly defined to have separate treatment. Is it administratively possible to vary National Insurance payments in this part of the United Kingdom alone? The answer to these questions was established as a result of the arguments my hon. Friends and I put in 161. It is a clear, "Yes". We have separate National Insurance powers in Northern Ireland and the stamps are differently over-stamped. Hon. Members may ask why trouble to exempt Northern Ireland, and in reply I should like to draw the attention of the Committee to the severity of the tax. In 1961 the right hon. and learned Gentleman the Member for Wirral introduced a payroll tax of 4s. Today this payroll tax is 25s.—many times more than that introduced, in 1961, then so strongly opposed by the Labour Party. The Chancellor made it clear during his Budget speech that this
tax raises the equivalent of either a shilling on income tax or almost double the present rate of purchase tax.
This is the weight of the tax, which will raise £300 million in the first year and about £240 million in succeeding years. Of that figure abut £8 million or £9 million is expected to come from Northern Ireland. The proportion of persons employed in the service industries in Northern Ireland is about 65 per cent. If one studies the statistics, one sees that the proportion employed in the service industries has been gradually increasing over the last 10 years, while the proportion employed in the manufacturing industries has been falling slightly. This is the mark of any advanced economy.
We are therefore going to impose this heavy burden on about 65 per cent. of the working population in Northern Ireland, and deliberately attempted to create unemployment among that percentage in the service industries. We have many industries in Northern Ireland which are already finding it difficult, with their higher transport costs—the cross-Channel cost—to compete with firms in the rest of the United Kingdom. Some firms are faced with fixed-price contracts which they are going to find very hard to fulfil.
I would like to single out the construction industry for particular comment. This industry will be greatly affected by the tax. It is an industry which we want to foster, to help provide new industry, clear our slums and build new housing. The Northern Ireland Minister of Finance, Mr. Herbert Kirk has made valiant efforts to mitigate the effects of the tax, but he said that the £2 million which has been received for Northern Ireland will only be a temporary rebate. This is reported in the Northern Ireland Official Report at col. 1684 on 31st May. Mr. Kirk said: Together these three schemes— referring to the three payments which have been mentioned— will use up the full allocation of £2 million. I cannot at present promise that I shall be able to continue the special refund concessions beyond 1966–67. It will almost certainly be impossible to continue them at the rates I have accepted for the first seven months of the Selective Employment Tax. The first seven months! We are getting a little mitigation for the first
seven months. I am trying to look beyond that. I would refer the Committee, briefly, because I appreciate that other hon. Members want to speak, to the speeches of right hon. Gentlemen opposite made on the same subject. I will not repeat the ones which have been mentioned by my right hon. Friend the Leader of the Opposition; they are fully reported in HANSARD for 23rd June this year, columns 957 and 958. They show clearly that the late Hugh Gaitskell, the right hon. Member for Battersea, North (Mr. Jay), now President of the Board of Trade, the right hon. Member for Belper (Mr. G. Brown), now Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, the right hon. Member for Birmingham, Stechford (Mr. Roy Jenkins), now Home Secretary, and the Prime Minister were opposed to applying the payroll tax to a development area, and all pointed out clearly in the speeches quoted by my right hon. Friend their doubts about this tax.
In addition to the speeches there quoted, the Secretary of State for the Colonies, the right hon. Member for Newton (Mr. Frederick Lee) said on 13th June, 1961, when the Amendment which I had down was being debated: I know that these are the problems facing the right hon. and learned Gentleman, and I do not wish to embarrass him too much. But we on this side of the Committee "—he was speaking for the whole Labour Party— are convinced that this Amendment is well worthy of our support. We shall support the hon. Gentleman and his friends in the Lobby at the end of this debate. A little later he said: The problem of Northern Ireland must not be shelved. The Government must never tried to meet the fact"— he was referring to the Conservative Government, unfairly— that consistently there has been a high rate of unemployment in Northern Ireland. From this side of the Committee we have tried to help … "—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 13th June, 1961; Vol. 642, c. 323.] I do not wish to weary the Committee by reading more extracts, but this gives the key to what a Front Bench spokesman for the then Opposition, now a member of the Government, felt in 1961. The present Prime Minister is reported as repeating similar sentiments. He concluded: We intend to support the Amendment in the Lobby, and I appeal to all my hon.
Friends to go into the Lobby now."—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 13th June, 1961; Vol. 642, c. 331.] I hope that he will support the Amendment today. I am sure that he will not turn about and change his mind just like that.
On 18th April, 1961, the Prime Minister, referring to the payroll tax, said: The Government would be most likely to introduce this payroll tax at a time of balance of payments difficulties"— he was referring to the payroll tax of my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Wirral (Mr. Selwyn Lloyd)— Had the Government had power to do this at that time it is clear that it would have intensified the depression and the growth of unemployment which was already on the way. The idea amazes me. Later he said: Has the right hon. and learned Gentleman considered the effect of the proposed 4s. payroll tax on the different industries in Britain? How, for instance, will it affect the hospital service, or local authorities, or the other one hundred essential services and industries in this country which are quite incapable of introducing automation? ".—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 18th April, 1961; Vol. 638, cc. 985–7.] On 19th April, 1961, the right hon. Member for Battersea, North, speaking about Northern Ireland and the payroll tax, said: But, quite apart from all that, it surely is rather a monumental piece of cynicism that we have been told for years that rises in labour costs would be inflationary and price us out of export markets and all the rest and now we are suddenly told that a rise in labour costs, provided it does not come through an increase in wages but through this tax, will be beneficial after all because it will stimulate industrial development … The truth, of course is"— the right hon. Member for Battersea, North said— that any direct charge on costs of this kind, whether the National Insurance contribution or this surcharge, is a direct addition to financial costs and, therefore, to prices, including those of exports … "—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 19th April, 1961; Vol. 638, c. 1291.] 8.45 a.m.
These few quotations show quite clearly what leading members of the present Government felt about a 4s. payroll tax, and particularly what they felt about its application to Northern Ireland. I do sincerely appeal to the Chancellor of the Exchequer to consider this most carefully between now and Report, to see if he would be prepared to accept this Amendment. If he is not prepared to
accept it in the words with which we have drafted it, perhaps he would be prepared to introduce his Amendment, along the same lines.
I have just one last point I should like to make. In Northern Ireland we are having a temporary repayment, but it must be remembered, with respect to manufacturing industries which my hon. and gallant Friend has referred to, that bank interest—overdraft—rates are higher than they are in the rest of the United Kingdom. Therefore, to our manufacturing industries the cost of meeting these tax payments and covering them for the three or four months before a repayment is made will be higher than it will be in the rest of the United Kingdom.
Why is Northern Ireland—why is the United Kingdom as a whole—being charged the cost of administering this tax when it is quite straightforward to exempt the whole of Northern Ireland from the tax? It seems to me a ridiculous suggestion that money should be gathered in one hand and held by the Government for a number of months and then refunded to those people who are making the payments. Where is the money to come from? If it is to come from banks, the overdraft rates will be 1 or 2 per cent. higher than those which manufacturers will have to pay here. I agree that there is a need to give subsidy to manufacturing industry in Northern Ireland, but I feel that this tax should be made part of the National Plan. It is, after all, a selective employment tax. Why should it not be selective regionally as well as between the two kinds of industry, manufacturing and servicing?
I suggest that the Chancellor has new talks with the Minister of Finance in Northern Ireland. I should like to make it clear—I think my hon. Friends agree with me, and they also support this Amendment—that we here are not acting as spokesmen of the Northern Ireland Government. We are acting as Ulster Unionist Members here. We have quite a different rôle to play. The right hon. Gentleman may say that the Minister of Finance in Northern Ireland is satisfied with the tax, but we have a responsibility to our constituents, and it is wider, I suggest, than that of the Minister of Finance. We have to look at the overall picture, the overall effect on our economy of this tax, and although the Minister of Finance
in Northern Ireland may be satisfied in so far as he has been given a concession, as, indeed, his predecessor was in 1961, I believe—or at least, so the Chancellor at that time said in Committee on the Finance Bill then—though the Minister of Finance may be satisfied because he finds it adminstratively possible to raise the tax, and he is content with the concessions. I suggest that, viewing the country as a whole, looking at the National Plan and realising that our unemployment is more persistent and difficult than that in any other part of the United Kingdom, the Government should go further and, as in 1961 they suggested should be done, exempt Northern Ireland completely from the tax.

As one of the two Dublin-born Irishmen in the Committee, my national sense of irony is slightly provoked at finding myself in the position of having to reply to this debate which involves a tendentious issue between hon. Members who represent Northern Ireland constituencies and the Government.
The intention of the promoters of the Amendment is to exempt Northern Ireland from the scope of the tax. While the Amendment would be effective to do that, I suspect that it was not intentionally that the hon. Members also achieved the intention of requiring employers of foreign-going mariners and airmen in Great Britain and Northern Ireland to pay the tax in the same way as other employers. That is one of the pitfalls, of which I have had great personal experience in opposition, of trying to draft Amendments to complicated Statutes.
As to the general intention, I will deal first with the administrative argument. The hon. Member for Belfast, East (Mr. McMaster) stated that there would be no difficulty administratively in excluding Northern Ireland. I would quote to him from the speech by Mr. Kirk, Minister of Finance in Northern Ireland, which the hon. Member quoted, who said at the outset of his remarks: Under the National Insurance Scheme, contributions paid in Northern Ireland are completely interchangeable with those paid in Great Britain. We could not, therefore, have stamps of a different value in Northern Ireland without inviting evasion on a serious scale. We thus have a tax introduced as part of the United Kingdom tax system and which
for practical purposes must apply in Northern Ireland. That proposition is entirely well founded. Although stamps in Northern Ireland may be over-printed "Northern Ireland", the fact is that any employer in this country would be perfectly free to purchase those stamps and then affix them to cards in this country, and when the Ministry of Pensions and National Insurance examined the cards at the end of the year there would be no way of checking whether or not the employee during the period had or had not been employed in Northern Ireland by a Northern Ireland employer, because none of these facts appears on the card. There are a great many workers who come from Northern Ireland, as from Southern Ireland, periodically for certain months of the year to work over here, then go back to their own country, and so on. So there would be nothing unusual in a card which had some Northern Ireland stamps on it as well as some British stamps.
I think I have said enough for hon. Members to see the reason why Mr. Kirk and the Northern Ireland Government accepted that it would not be possible administratively to exclude Northern Ireland from the scope of the tax without inviting evasion on a serious scale.

I appreciate the hon. and learned Gentleman's statement that with the present system of raising National Insurance stamps there would be certain difficulties in having a differential rate in Northern Ireland and that there would be difficulties if the Government raised the tax differently in Northern Ireland from the way it was done in Great Britain. This is not surprising, because the Government are using the National Insurance stamp system for a purpose for which it was never designed. But is the hon. and learned Gentleman seriously suggesting 'that the mighty British Treasury is not capable of developing some simple administrative system whereby this could be done. Having been an administrative officer, I always reckoned that it was a challenge to the administrator, that one could always find a system to carry out almost anything. We have had far too many arguments throughout the Finance Bill
to the affect that things are administratively difficult.

If we had had the pleasure of the hon. Member's company throughout the very interesting debates which we have had on the Clause, he would have heard it explained many times at considerable length why, in order to introduce the tax this year, it was necessary to tie it in this way to the National Insurance stamp system. The answer to his question, would it not have been practicable to devise some simple method of raising the tax this year other than through the National Insurance stamp, is no; it was not possible. That is why the tax is being raised in this form.
The hon. Member for Belfast, East has pointed out that he is not speaking for the Northern Ireland Government in this matter, but for his constituents in Northern Ireland. It was agreed by the hon. and gallant Member for Down, South (Captain Orr) at the outset of his speech that Northern Ireland accepts the obligations as well as the benefits of membership of the United Kingdom. Consequently, in general, it accepts its liability to pay United Kingdom taxes.
He raised a point about the legal rights of Northern Ireland and asked whether the tax does not fall within the scope of the transferred taxes. That position is accepted by both Governments, and specific provision is made for it in the Bill under subsection (8), which safeguards the legal position. There is no question about that. Theoretically, it would have been possible for the Northern Ireland Government themselves to have introduced a Bill for the raising of the tax in Northern Ireland separately, but it was obviously more convenient for them as well as for us if it was all covered by legislation from here, it being made clear in that legislation that the full rights of the Northern Ireland Government are preserved in this matter.
On the question as to whether Northern Ireland should have been exempted from the scope of the tax, once again I will quote Mr. Kirk's budget speech. Dealing with the point, he said: In considering the impact of the tax on Northern Ireland, we must not fall into the error of thinking that the alternative is no extra tax at all. It is quite obvious from the Chan-
cellor's Budget speech that he had decided to raise additional taxation and would have increased other taxes if the Selective Employment Tax were not available. It is anyone's guess what the other taxes would have been, but most people seemed to be expecting increases on petrol, purchase tax, drink and tobacco, vehicle licences, or Income Tax. It is impossible to be precise, but for almost any likely combination of these taxes, the Northern Ireland taxpayer would contribute about the same as the net yield of the Selective Employment Tax, or perhaps rather more. I would cite that in answer to the suggestion that this is a form of tax which falls in an unduly burdensome way on Northern Ireland. There is reason to think that it falls rather less harshly on Northern Ireland than on other areas, again for a reason which was referred to by Mr. Kirk, when he went on: One reason for the comparatively light impact of the Selective Employment Tax in Northern Ireland is that it does not apply to the self-employed, who represent a high proportion of our working population compared with Great Britain. The hon. Member for Belfast, East asked why the selection in the Selective Employment Tax could not be operated regionally. The arguments which were adduced in support of the Amendment were arguments with which we are familiar and heard on those Amendments which were urging regional differentials. Northern Ireland is in a special and fortunate position in that respect. The effect of that and the special rates in relation to transferred taxes is that the tax is being operated regionally in a special way. The reason is that the equivalent Bill, the Selective Employment Payments Bill, is a matter which will be legislated upon by the Northern Ireland Parliament for Northern Ireland. It will be for them to decide in effect what to do with the gross yield of this tax from Northern Ireland. The yield will be about £ 6½ million, and, as has been pointed out, all this money will be made available to the Northern Ireland Exchequer.
The Northern Ireland Government have already taken their own decisions in relation to this matter, and they have decided to make refunds and payments beyond those which we are providing for under our Payments Bill. In effect these will take three forms, one of which has been referred to a number of times, namely, the additional payments which will be made to manufacturing employers. As has been stressed, this is a temporary
scheme in order, as Mr. Kirk described it to soften the immediate impact of the tax and to give employers a breathing space in order to adjust themselves to the new tax." There will, in effect, be a 50 per cent. refund for them. 9.0 a.m.
The second way is by additional payments of 50 per cent. to local authorities to give them what Mr. Kirk described as some relief by providing them with what may perhaps best be described as some working capital. Thirdly, special payments are being made to employers in relation to apprentice training and to encourage apprentice training.
Because of the special problems of male employment and apprentice training in Northern Ireland, the Northern Ireland Government have decided, and have been in the fortunate position of being able to make a special repayment scheme beyond that which will apply throughout the rest of the United Kingdom.

To assist us to assess the financial meaning of these figures, it would be helpful if the right hon. Gentleman could say what proportion of the gross yield of the tax in Northern Ireland will, as a result of these measures, be returned to individuals, and how this compares with the position in England. I ask this because of the large proportion of service industries and workers in the six counties.

The gross yield for Northern Ireland is £6½ million. The repayment scheme which the Northern Ireland Government have adopted will involve a total of £2 million out of that £6½ million being refunded. Of this, £150,000 will go to the local authorities under that part of the scheme which relates to them. The rest will go to the employers of male labour and of apprentices in the manufacturing sector.

I am sure that the right hon. Gentleman does not wish to mislead the Committee. He has referred to Mr. Kirk's speech. If the right hon. Gentleman looks at column 1681 he will see that the figure of £6·5 million is not gross, but net yield. The gross yield is more like £8 million.

I was using the term "gross yield" as excluding the extra repayments. The hon. Gentleman is right if he refers to the gross yield as the yield before deducting the cost of collection, administrative expenses, and so on. The yield before these repayments are made is £6½ million.
Is the figure of £2 million the total payable to manufacturing as well as to service industries?

Yes, as I understand it. The full details are set out in Mr. Kirk's speech. This is a matter for the Northern Ireland Government, but as it has been referred to I thought it right to state my understanding of the position.

From the figures which the right hon. Gentleman has given it appears that about 25 per cent. of the total yield from the tax will be repaid to individual employers, one way or another. How does this compare with the position in England and Wales?

I would need notice of that question. If the hon. Gentleman cares to put down a Question we can give the precise figures. But the sums which are returned are, of course, substantially higher in Northern Ireland than in the rest of the scheme in Great Britain.
In conclusion, I would point out that so far from manufacturers in Northern Ireland being at any disadvantage under this scheme compared with manufacturers in Great Britain, they will in fact as a result of the measures adopted by the Northern Ireland Government on the repayment side be at quite an appreciable advantage.

I have listened with great care to the Financial Secretary's remarks, and just two points struck me initially as a little surprising.
First he referred to the large number of people who come from Northern Ire-land to Great Britain seasonal for employment. This comes as a surprise to me, as also does his statement that S.E.T. will fall less harshly on Northern Ireland owing to the high proportion of self-employed people. I presume agriculture must be included in this because we
have a substantial number of farmers operating their own farms and who are not employees of anybody else.
I do not wish to duplicate any of the arguments of my hon. Friends, but I would like to make one or two additional points and concentrate on what in my view will be the most hard hit industry in Northern Ireland—the tourist trade. I did not participate in the debate on the hotels earlier in the night because I wanted to reserve my remarks on this subject for this debate.
Judging by the bias in the S.E.T. against the service industries and anything remotely connected with them, one would almost imagine there was something wrong with the concept of service industries. I would like to nail this impression from the outset. Development of the tourist trade in Northern Ireland has been one of our notable accomplishments in recent years. The great scenic beauty of the province has been progressively developed, and the development programme for the whole of the hotel and catering industry has ensured that it is now a flourishing industry by any standards. But the consequence of this tax can only be to penalise savagely an efficient and effective industry.
Tourist revenue in Northern Ireland now represents a major item of revenue. I think that the figure for the tourist trade for last year, and I speak from memory, topped £20 million. All that we have built up by hard work and enterprise is now going to be hit very savagely by the Chancellor's tax.
As with the Highlands of Scotland, so with Northern Ireland—tourism and agriculture are two of the major industries, and much effort has been expended in recent years in advertising the tourist potential of Northern Ireland. But the industry is going to be hit very seriously indeed by this tax. I know it will be argued that the tourist trade is seasonal and thus variable, but that is a reflection on the climate rather than on the tourist industry. There surely can be no argument whatever advanced against the effect which deflation, which is one of the objects of this tax, would unquestionably have on the level of employment in Northern Ireland.
As I understand it, the Chancellor and the Treasury Ministers who have spoken in debates on this tax have all argued
in its support that they are disturbed by the drift of the working population into service rather than into manufacturing industries and that the economy is overheating and a measure of Treasury intervention is required. These are not contradictory arguments, but whichever of these arguments is applied to Northern Ireland I would have thought that they are both valid arguments for not imposing a tax on the Province.
Northern Ireland is still primarily an agricultural community, and that makes it wrong to steer people into other industries. One of the great problems of farming and agriculture in Northern Ireland, with its high proportion of small farms, has been the shortage of working capital. That has been the besetting problem for many years, and this tax, although it will ultimately be recouped by those engaged in farming, for example, after a time lag of three months, it will be bound to have injurious effects.
In America it has been argued that one of the hallmarks of a progressive community is a proper balance between the service and manufacturing industries. In Northern Ireland we have this balance, and it would be very serious if anything happened to upset the equilibrium between the two types of industry.
The argument about the overheating of the economy may be valid in the Midlands of England, but it is not valid in Northern Ireland. My hon. Friend the Member for Belfast, East (Mr. McMaster) and my hon. and gallant Friend the Member for Down, South (Captain Orr) have emphasised that deflation in Northern Ireland is bound to aggravate the already high level of unemployment. Surely it would be tragic, by any standards, if the Province, which at present is forging ahead economically as never before—with more people in employment than at any time in history—should receive a setback as a result of deliberate Government policy. I use the word "deliberate" advisedly, in the sense that it has been the general idea of the Treasury to apply this tax right across the board. That tax may have the desired effect in England, in the great conurbations, but it is bound to have an adverse effect in Northern Ireland, owing to its indiscriminate application regionally and geographically, and also in respect of the categories to which it applies.
My hon. Friends have argued that there should be some geographical variation in the tax, and it is also fair to argue that there should be some variation in respect of the categories affected. My hon. and gallant Friend the Member for Down, South handed me a letter during this debate which he received from a constituent engaged in the construction industry. It may interest the Committee if I cite one or two of the facts in support of the case for that industry. This gentleman is engaged on a contract valued at £4·2 million and the Selective Employment Tax on this contract will amount to £75,000. I accept that this will be reduced by half, as a temporary measure, over the first year, but expressed another way this represents five years' gross dividend of that company. I would have thought that this reflected the gravity of the effect of the tax on the construction industry.
My hon. Friend the Member for Belfast, East referred to the cost of borrowing money in Northern Ireland. Assuming that certain persons who will have to pay the tax will have to borrow the money from banks in order to pay it, even if it is subsequently refunded by the Treasury—if they are engaged in agriculture, for instance—the overdraft rate in Northern Ireland is higher than it is in England. It is indeed too high. It is roughly 1 per cent. above the English level. The English level is about 7 per cent., and the Northern Ireland rate is 8 per cent. and a bit. But to refer to a difference of 1 per cent. is misleading, because if we take the figure of 8 per cent. in relation to the figure of 7 per cent. we see that it is one-seventh, or 14 per cent. [Laughter.] This is a fair point. This is the effect which this will have on those people unfortunate enough to have to borrow the money.
For the reasons which I have given, I hope that, despite the interim statement of the Financial Secretary, he will give serious consideration to the situation which will develop in Northern Ireland because of the indiscriminate application of the tax.
Mr. Srrafton Mills rose——
Oh, no.

If the Treasury Bench can restrain their groans until the end of my speech, I should be obliged.
My hon. Friend the Member for Belfast, South (Mr. Pounder) said that Northern Ireland was forging ahead economically and the Treasury Bench seemed to think that they could take the credit. They would do well to reflect that the credit for this economic advance over a period belongs mainly to the Northern Ireland Government. I emphasise that when a Government, such as the present lot, move into the realms of theoretical taxation—which will have some benefits, I admit—they are bound to produce anomaly after anomaly.
My hon. and gallant Friend the Member for South Down (Captain Orr) has rightly pinpointed the anomaly in applying the Selective Employment Tax to an area with an abnormally high percentage of unemployment. Why has the Chancellor called the tax the "Selective" Employment Tax? What is selective about it? If the Treasury Ministers are prepared to divide industry between manufacturing and non-manufacturing—to be selective to that extent—I cannot see why they are not prepared to follow the logic of their own argument and go on in human terms to divide between the prosperous areas in the South-East and the Midlands, with a shortage of jobs, and the other parts of the country which are struggling all the time to maintain employment. I cannot understand why the Government should run so directly contrary to the many other things which, I accept, they are trying to do in their regional policy.
I listened to the speech of the Financial Secretary with growing horror. I appreciate that it is after his breakfast time and certainly after his bed time, and that he may not be putting the debating points with his usual sparkle to which we have become accustomed over the past two years, but I felt that his reply was completely irrelevant to the human problems which will be posed in an area like Northern Ireland by this tax.
He said that the tax would bear less harshly in Northern Ireland. Is it not clear that he thereby admitted that it will have a harsh effect in Northern Ireland? He used the words "less harshly", and that, he will admit——

I do not want the hon. Member to take a false point. It was being urged that the tax would fall more harshly. Taxpayers always consider that any imposition of tax is harsh. It falls more harshly on some and less harshly on others. Those who have the lighter burden are those on whom it falls less harshly.

That is a nicely balanced semantic point, but I reiterate that when the hon. and learned Gentleman reads his words in HANSARD—whenever he gets his HANSARD—he will see that the point which he was admitting was that it will have a harsh effect. I do not see how he can argue to the contrary when we are dealing with an area of high unemployment.
The Financial Secretary put very great stress on the administrative reasons for the tax. I followed him in the problems relating to National Insurance and the stamp system and the possibility of fraud. I would answer his point in this way. The whole system of the refunds has been geared to deal with this kind of problem, and I would have thought that if the Government had the will they could easily have fitted in a system of refunds to ensure that no fraudulent means were operating in the scheme.
The Financial Secretary has referred to the refund of 12s. 6d. which the Northern Ireland Minister of Finance is making to the service industries. As my hon. Friend the Member for Belfast, East (Mr. McMaster) pointed out, this is of a strictly temporary nature. The Financial Secretary could make an additional contribution to the debate by giving an assurance that there will be no pressure placed on the Northern Ireland Minister of Finance to stop that repayment while the Northern Ireland rate of unemployment remains at its present high level.
If one looks at the facts, one finds that the Northern Ireland Minister of Finance is in this difficulty, that he has to prepare his Budget on matters like this largely on guidance and pressure from the Treasury. If this matter could be considered while unemployment remains high, it would be a most valuable assurance from the Financial Secretary. I hope he will not feel unduly restrained from intervening before we divide this morning and giving some kind of assurance that pressure will not be exerted on
the Northern Ireland Government to stop this system of refunds when they present their next Budget.
It is clear from the words of the Northern Ireland Minister of Finance that he envisages that those special refunds will only be of a temporary nature, and he always has the albatross from the Treasury in Whitehall hanging over his shoulder.
I am glad to see the hon. Member for Belfast, West (Mr. Fitt) in his place. I think all hon. Members know that he is of a very shy nature and is always embarrassed at intervening in debates like this. Of course, he is very lucky in that he represents a constituency at Stormont and at Westminster, and if there is an embarrassing debate at Stormont he can always come here to Westminster, while if there is an embarrassing debate at Westminster he can go to Stormont.
I would be very interested to hear the views of the hon. Member for Belfast, West on this tax because I noticed to my astonishment that he voted for the Government, presumably to ingratiate himself with them, on the Second Reading of the Bill on 25th May. When the Ways and Means Resolution on this tax was being considered he was absent, and while the Committee has been considering the whole principle of the Selective Employment Tax I find that he has voted on one occasion, in favour of the Tax but he has been absent on eight occasions, I know not where. That, of course, is only my tally up to half-past Ten last night. When we see the HANSARD report tomorrow it may show that he has been further supporting the Selective Employment Tax in the Lobby.
I hope the hon. Member will accept these remarks in a good-natured fashion and will not feel that he should sit quietly by and not let us hear his views. My constituency is next door to his and I know there will be many people in his constituency who will suffer very severely from this tax. I should have thought that he would have been wiser to pay attention to their interests rather than to engage in his perpetual task of ingratiating himself with the small noisy anti-Ulster wing in the party opposite.

It is rather ironic that when the Financial Secretary opened
his speech on this Amendment he told us that he was born and bred in Dublin, and then proceeded to make a speech without mentioning the unemployment problem in Northern Ireland in any way whatsoever. How right we have been in Northern Ireland for many years to resist the possibility of a Dublin Government.
The unemployment problem in Northern Ireland is often looked at rather cynically and superficially, particularly by those on the Treasury Bench. I want to make it clear that the areas I have in mind are not those with 5 per cent. or 6 per cent. unemployment. They are areas, forty or fifty miles from Belfast, where the unemployment levels run at about 14 or 15 per cent. in some parts and certainly at a fairly steady level of 12 per cent. If hon. Members opposite think that that level is a matter for hilarity, I do not.
In these areas, the one thing needed above all is new enterprises and industries, however small. I oppose this tax for Northern Ireland because it is basically deflationary and will make it much more difficult to get those new enterprises in manufacturing, tourism and services. They would help to bring down this appalling figure of unemployment in the small and fairly remote villages where it hits the population so hard and saps its moral fibre. But anyone who sits down to work out trial balances for new enterprises in the light of this tax will realise its effect upon profitability and incentives. A large number of those contemplating establishing new enterprises in these areas will decide against it because of the tax.
We have been told that the tax will not hit Northern Ireland harshly. That is ridiculous. The Financial Secretary knows as well as we do that the general level of wages in Northern Ireland is considerably lower than it is here. Therefore, the tax there will entail a much higher percentage of the wage bill than it will in most parts of Great Britain.

On the same point about harshness, I would call my hon. Friend's attention to what the Financial Secreary said in reply to my intervention earlier. I understood the hon. and learned Gentleman to imply
that Northern Ireland was being treated more generously than other parts of the United Kingdom in terms of the amount of money being paid. It looks as if about 25 per cent. is going back to the six counties whereas the figure is 68 per cent. for England.

I may have misled the hon. Member for Perth and East Perthshire (Mr. MacArthur) by not making it clear that the £2 million referred to by Mr. Kirk in his speech is additional to the repayments which we are providing for Great Britain. That is to say, over and above the 30 per cent. refund in the manufacturing sector, there will be additional refunds totalling £2 million out of the net yield of £6½ million for Northern Ireland.
That still is not equal to the 68 per cent. for England.
Order. We cannot have interruptions in interruptions.

The tax hits Northern Ireland harder than it does Great Britain. The wage level there is lower than it is here. One of the things that people over there smile at rather grimly is the boasting of both Governments that the average wage in England is £15. It is not so in Northern Ireland, so that the tax will be a considerable percentage of the average wage in most parts of my constituency. Thus, an industry in Northern Ireland will be much harder hit than its competitor in Great Britain.
Northern Ireland has a land frontier and across the border we face hot competition in tourism. Our tourist industry is in competition with County Louth and County Donegal in the Republic. There is there a highly subsidised industry with a rather lower level of wages, and against this we have fewer subsidies in Northern Ireland. Our tourist industry is in direct competition, resort against resort 20 miles apart—only five miles in some cases—and it is having to meet this tax. It is easy for the Financial Secretary to neglect this point. It would be interesting if he could produce a convincing argument about it.
9.30 a.m.
The complete inappropriateness of the tax in areas such as Northern Ireland is brought out finally in the preference that
it gives to female employment. It is well known that in Northern Ireland, and in many areas of this sort, there is a higher proportion of employment for females than for men. We want more jobs for men, yet higher rates of tax are to apply to men than to women.
It will pay the owner of a petrol service station in a fairly remote area in my constituency, where there are no jobs for men, to sack the man who runs the station and employ a woman instead. Is that the kind of object that the tax is designed to achieve? There is an infinite number of points of inappropriateness and complete nonsense about the tax if applied to such an area as Northern Ireland.
If the Government cannot accept the Amendment, can we have an assurance, either now or on Report, on whether Mr. Kirk will be able to continue his relief after next April, and whether the Government will back Mr. Kirk when he introduces the rather quicker system of repayment than the five or six months which we have been promised?
We have talked in terms of £6 million or £8 million. The Chancellor is anxious to have the maximum amount of money taken out of the economy by 1st January, the date on which he has promised to balance the books. I do not think that £6 million or £8 million here will help the Chancellor to balance his books. Can we have an assurance that the repayment can be made rather quicker in Northern Ireland than elsewhere in the United Kingdom?
Following up the remarks of my hon. Friend the Member for Belfast, East (Mr. McMaster), I say that we would welcome hon. Members opposite in the Lobby when we divide on the Amendment, and we would particularly welcome the presence of the hon. Member for Belfast, West (Mr. Fitt).

We have had a very good debate. My hon. Friends have put the case for this exemption with great cogency and skill. I am sorry that they have failed to persuade the Financial Secretary and the Treasury of the case, and I am also sorry that we have such a disappointing reply. None the less,
it might be a good thing to come to a conclusion on the matter fairly soon, and I so recommend to my hon. Friends.

My hon. Friend the Member for Belfast, East (Mr. McMaster) may inadvertently have given the impression that the Ulster Unionist hon. Members had not been from the very beginning opposed to the notion of a tax upon employment. The fact remains that we are absolutely united in opposition, both in the past and now, against any tax placed specifically upon employment as such. We think that it is totally irrelevant and grotesque to apply such a tax in Northern Ireland. Our difference in the past may have been about methods of achieving our object.

My second purpose is to express our disappointment at the Financial Secretary's reply. He did not meet our arguments at all. He used two arguments, as I thought he would, which were totally irrelevant. It is disappointing also that he did not respond to the request for an undertaking made by my hon. Friend the Member for Belfast, North (Mr. Stratton Mills). Will he now say something about that?

I gladly do so. I should have thought it almost unnecessary. It would be quite inappropriate for us to seek to bring any pressure one way or another upon the Northern Ireland Government in regard to how to deal with the question of refunds, how long to continue their present scheme, and so on.
